awd_titl_txt: Molecular Control over the Mechanism of Crystal Growth
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
Control of crystalline structure is important to the application of materials, whether to control the activity of pharmaceuticals or the electronic conductivity of advanced materials.  However, deciphering the physical/chemical processes that determine growth of specific crystal structures is complex.  This project systematically measures the influence of molecular shape and the strength of intermolecular interactions on the kinetics of crystal growth to investigate molecular level control of the mechanism of melt crystallization.  In addition to advancing the fundamental science, this work is invaluable to all fields of science for which crystal growth is critical, such as polymers, pharmaceuticals, food products, geology, and atmospheric science. In addition, professional development for high school chemistry teachers is made available across the state of North Carolina. This discipline based professional development helps teachers shift curricula from a standardized test-based content/algorithm focus to critical-thinking/problem-solving based teaching and learning.

Technical Abstract:
The research supported by this award uniquely presents a melt crystallization strategy that directly probes the influence of intrinsic factors of molecular shape and intermolecular forces on the mechanism of crystal growth. Experimental measurement of the crystallization kinetics of oligoacenes and alkylammonium metal halide salts, as a function of the number of aromatic rings and length of alkyl chains, respectively, is being used to probe the impact of molecular anisotropy and crystal dimensionality on the rate of crystallization. Comparative kinetic measurements from isotropic vs. oriented melts of liquid crystals is utilized to articulate the impact of molecular pre-orientation on the rate of crystallization. Also, the crystallization kinetics across the family of substituted benzenes creates a geometric and energetic matrix with which to evaluate functional group effects.  The PI's recent discovery of Transition Zone Theory, the condensed matter analog of Eyring's transition state theory, enables for the identification of entropic and enthalpic activation parameters of crystallization reactions. This award facilitates a continuing offering of the summer teacher workshops, and also supports hiring a high school chemistry teacher to work with the PI during summers to write and publish components of this professional development, which affords greater dissemination of the problem-solving/discovery based materials.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

As a student in general chemistry class nearly 40 years ago, I was taught that because the concentration of solids and liquids does not change during the course of a reaction, they do not appear in kinetic rate expressions.  And yet, fundamental reactions such as crystal growth from a melt are temperature-dependent, activated processes that only involve solids and liquid.  Should there not also be rate laws governing the kinetics of reactions of pure liquids and solids?  Little did I understand how this unanswered question from freshman chemistry would come to shape my career.

Over more than two decades of independent research, including support from five NSF grants, I and my students/research associates discovered the Transition Zone Theory of crystallization, TZTc, which accurately describes the temperature dependent rate of crystal growth from melts that occurs between a material’s glass transition temperature and its melting temperature.  Our theory is built on understanding the cooperative interactions of ensembles of atoms/molecules to describe condensed matter processes, rather traditional approaches that attempt to describe condensed matter using independent particle assumptions.  In work supported by this most recent NSF grant, we benchmarked our TZTc, against classical theories.  Without exception, our TZTc model yields a superior fit to both new, and previously published, experimental temperature-dependent crystal growth-rate data.  Our single model that accurately describes diverse crystallizing systems, for the first time, provides a platform with which to compare and contrast chemical/physical factors that influence crystallization reactions.

Each of the parameters from the TZTc model (enthalpic and entropic activation barriers and a temperature dependent cooperativity parameter) have a sound physical-chemical basis, which we used to examine functional group influences on crystal growth rates.  This work included the first comprehensive isotope effect measurements of crystal growth rates.  Measuring the relative crystal growth kinetics of the d0, d1, d9 and d10 isotopologues of the halozeotype CZX-1, [(H/D)N(C(H/D)3)3]CuZn5Cl12, revealed novel understanding of how molecular templates control the crystal growth rates of inorganic networks.  The differential kinetics of the 16OH2, 16OD2 and 18OH2 isotopologues of the crystalline hydrate [Zn(OH2)6][ZnCl4] revealed how hydrogen bonding and proton mobility control the rate of crystalline hydrate formation.  Evaluation of literature-data for a series of ortho-substituted benzene molecules and poly-alcohols revealed that introduction of molecular degrees of freedom has a greater effect on crystal growth rates than does introduction of strong hydrogen-bonding functional groups.  Other analyses demonstrated the correlation between structural networks and crystal growth rates of alkali-silicates and, further, that systems with highly mobile cations exhibit very large negative entropies of activation, consistent with the need to restrict ionic mobility in order to construct the long-range-order of a crystalline lattice.

The research supported by this grant was clearly focused on the discovery of fundamental science, yielding deeper understanding of how atoms and molecules can interact to form materials.  With crystal growth being critical to scientific areas as diverse as earth and atmospheric systems, pharmaceuticals, and advanced materials technology, we expect our fundamental discoveries to be widely applied.  

Our discovery and application of transition zone theory stands in comparison to Arrhenius’ and Eyring’s discovery of transition state theory in the early 20th century.  The latter has been transformational with respect to understanding molecular level control of chemical reactions in dilute media.  We submit that our transition zone theory will be similarly transformational for understanding and controlling condensed matter reactions. 

Broader Impact

This grant also supported high school chemistry teacher professional development (ChemPD).  I and my students created and offer two ChemPD workshops each summer free of charge to high school chemistry teachers across the state of North Carolina (paused due to COVID).  These two-day workshops work with teachers to develop discovery- and critical thinking-based approaches to education.  In addition to offering these workshops, novel hands-on experiments were developed whereby students can discover, as opposed to being told about chemical principles.  Working with a teacher intern, we developed a novel integrated approach to a chemistry curriculum described as a Web of Study for Chemistry. Instead of a traditional linear course of study for which lists of standards tend to shift teaching and learning toward coverage, our Web of Study approach emphasizes integration of concepts by which learners build a coherent and self-consistent body of knowledge.  While providing important contexts to understand the relevance and relationships of new material being learned, the visual representation of content through the Web of Chemistry facilitates seeing and thinking about interrelationships, provides a framework with which to formulate logical explanations of observed phenomena, and stimulates the most fundamental process of science: asking new questions…such as the ones I started asking more than 40 years ago and which ultimately became the basis for this grant.
